author: Mason Nesbitt
title: Hart football's Presley crucial to rushing resurgence
text:
Hart football's Presley crucial to rushing resurgence Indians center has provided stability to offensive line Posted: October 7, 2015 10:56   7, 2015 10:56 p.m. Hart senior center Nick Presley has helped the Indians record 183 rushing yards per game so far this season, up more than 50 yards from last year. Signal photo by Dan Watson 
In writing it’s called a lead or a hook, or whatever you want to call a story’s beginning as long as it grabs the reader’s attention and yanks them deeper into the text. 
The first clip on Nick Presley’s 2014 highlight tape is spellbinding. 
The then-junior offensive guard drives a linebacker back for 15 yards before depositing him on his rear, allowing the Hart High ball carrier to scamper nearly untouched into the end zone. 
Just another day at the office for the “big, mean guy up front,” in the words of Hart junior quarterback Nick Moore. 
Beyond the ferocity and flat-out ability is a mild-mannered joker, a quick-thinking strategist and a guy meant — even destined — for the offensive line. 
And not just any line: specifically the one in Newhall. The one that needed one final piece in 2013 and a stabilizing force in 2015. 
Needless to say, Presley’s delivered. 
“If he doesn’t know what he’s doing then nobody does,” Moore says of Presley, now Hart’s starting center. “But he always knows what he’s doing.” 
That’s been especially crucial this season, a five-game span in which Hart has already used roughly nine different offensive linemen due, in part, to a knee issue that sidelined NCAA Division I talent Colby Pursell for the first four games (the left tackle returned against Ventura last week). 
But at the center of it all — literally — has been Presley, who’s started every game. 
The 6-foot-2-inch, 260-pound senior transitioned seamlessly from guard to center this season (he did play some center last year and as a freshman) and has already earned the praise and faith of his team in his ability to make protection calls — even in the just handful of seconds from the time the play is hollered out to the moment Moore initiates the Indians’ no-huddle offense. 
Presley’s handle on the position has allowed him to help put younger substitute linemen in positions for success. 
“He’s almost like a second coach on the field,” Moore says. 
And the Indians have hardly missed a beat. Through four wins and a heartbreaking, controversial loss to highly-touted St. Bonaventure, the Indians have run for a Foothill League-leading 183.2 yards per game, up more than 50 yards from last season. 
That’s given Hart the balance it hoped for in replacing the dynamic quarterback-wide receiver duo of Brady White and Trent Irwin from a year ago. 
The rushing ability of Moore and running back Nelson James has been crucial, but it’d be hard not to credit the Presley-led offensive line. 
“What (Presley has) done really well this year — better than most years — is he’s blocking at the next level,” says Hart head coach Mike Herrington. “You have the front four and then the linebackers, and he’s doing a much better job of blocking at the second level of the defense.” 
This season isn’t the first time Presley’s been in the right spot at the right time for Hart. 
In 2013, he transferred from Crespi High of Encino to a Hart team in need of a left guard. 
Presley stepped in and, without giving him too much glory, the rest — namely Hart’s 2013 CIF-Southern Section Northern Division title — is history. 
“They embraced me like a family, and it couldn’t have been better,” Presley says of joining the Indians. 
That atmosphere provides a snapshot of what Presley loves most about playing offensive line. 
“Just that you have five brothers that have your back every single play — just the chemistry and the bond that I made. That’s what I really, really appreciate,” he says. 
But maybe equal to that, the position seems to run in his blood. 
Presley’s dad, Steve, played guard in high school. 
His uncle, Jeff, played center. His uncle, Greg, played tackle. 
And his cousin, Clay, suited up for the University of Memphis as ... a lineman. 
“He’s been a lineman his whole life,” Steve says of Nick. “Our family are linemen. We can play the game without a ball for the most part.” 
The Presleys moved to the Santa Clarita Valley from Chesapeake, Va., when Nick was 4, and he took up football around the time he was 7. 
He loved the game, and he loved to play. 
That sometimes meant pulling his jersey over his head while snapping the ball, Steve says, or at other times assuming a bizarre stance on extra point tries or employing a goofy running style on laps. 
“He was always messing around, trying to joke,” Steve says. 
That easy-going quality proved handy in keeping teammates loose around the St. Bonaventure game, Steve says. But it hardly precludes Presley from getting after it. 
For example: he put on roughly 20 pounds between his sophomore and junior seasons. 
“He lifts like crazy,” Steve says. “I don’t want to misquote his numbers. He’s got crazy high numbers on the weightlifting.” 
Asked about Presley’s best playing traits, Herrington agreed, “His aggressiveness, his blocks, his technique. He has good strength.” 
One coach, Steve says, told Presley he should consider giving up football for weightlifting competitions and a run at the Olympics. 
Presley has stayed with football — helping drive Hart toward a possible Foothill League title 1 yard at a time. 
Or maybe in chunks of 15.
